user.biography:
Whale Researcher - Bay Cetology
Whale Research Assistant - @oceanwiseresearch 
Cowichan Bay, Vancouver Island

node.text:
Awesome day today with 11 Biggs killer whales being very social! the group comprised of the T035As, T038As, T137B, T137D and the T075Bs (photo I took of T075B spyhopping in the background). All vocals and video was prepared by @taslishaw 

Turn up the volume and enjoy some of the calls these whales were making today! 

#killerwhale #orca #whale #nofishnoblackfish

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Gary Sutton on August 08, 2021. May be an image of body of water.

node.text:
Another successful day for our @oceanwiseresearch photogrammetry team! We caught up with the I4s and I65 northern resident matrilines resting in Blackney Pass. After conducting one successful flight over them, we moved on to try and find the I27s who had also been in the area. 

Eventually we got them a few miles away from the rest. Spread out and foraging which is always nice to see. As we were landing the drone after the successful flight over them, I27 “Sointula” did this which took us all by surprise! You can see the video on the @oceanwiseresearch page in their stories.

Members of the team are now analyzing the aerial data we collected today and can use them to assess the animals health or “fatness” and compare the photos/measurements from today to previous years with the same individual.

📷Credit: Ocean Wise Research, DFO Marine Mammal Licence, MML18

⚠️ It is illegal to fly drones or approach killer whales closer than 200m if not under permit

#killerwhale #orca #oceanwiseresearch #whale #research #northernresidents

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Gary Sutton on August 06, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Research trip number two with @oceanwiseresearch has started off in classic north island fashion! Rolling clouds over the mountains, a gentle mist, a bit of fog and, of course, some northern resident killer whales. 

For those that don’t know, our team uses drones to capture aerial photos of killer whales (mainly northern residents) to determine their “fatness” and relative health.

We were able to conduct six successful drone flights over the I65s, I27s and the I4s today. They were being super cooperative travelling in tight resting groups. 

Here is I122 this morning :).

This was day one of our 4-5 week research trip and to follow more of our work, you can follow us at @oceanwiseresearch where we will be providing field season updates throughout the summer. You can also follow #owresearchupdates to keep up to date.

📷Credit: Ocean Wise Research, DFO Marine Mammal Licence, MML18

⚠️ It is illegal to fly drones or approach killer whales closer than 200m if not under permit

#killerwhale #orca #oceanwiseresearch #whale

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Gary Sutton on July 24, 2021 tagging @junglejane89. May be an image of nature and ocean.

node.text:
Brother and sister, T137A and T137B, swimming off into the sunset tonight. Such a beautiful moment and made me think of my sister @byoungxoxo and wishing I could be with her right now after the birth of her first child! 
#orca #whale #nikon #nikontop #killerwhale #sunset #beautifulbritishcolumbia #explorebc #pnw #pacificnorthwest #idigthebiggs #unclegary

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Gary Sutton on July 23, 2021. May be an image of body of water and nature.

node.text:
The T034, T037 and T046 matrilines have been hanging around in the Salish Sea a lot lately. A good indication that we are well into summer! You know you’re a whale nerd when….you determine what season it is based on what killer whale matriline is around 😂.
#killerwhale #orca #whale #nikon #beautifulbritishcolumbia #explorebc #pnw #pacificnorthwest #biggsarethebalance #idigthebiggs

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Gary Sutton on July 18, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Went out for a rip today with @ocean_eco ! We ended up catching up with some northern resident killer whales, the A42s, which was a bit of a surprise. These whales aren’t common in the Salish Sea especially during the summer months.
On our way back, @taslishaw spotted a group of 16 Bigg’s killer whales too! Here’s a pic of some of the T090, T034 and T037 matrilines grouped up. Photo number two is the unmistakable northern resident dorsal fin of A79 “Current” with her 2018 calf, A119 “Venture” popping up beside her.
#killerwhale #orca #whale #nikon #beautifulbritishcolumbia #explorebc #vancouverisland #idigthebiggs #biggsarethebalance #saveoursalmon #northernresidents #pnw #pacificnorthwest

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Gary Sutton on July 18, 2021. May be an image of nature.
Photo by Gary Sutton on July 18, 2021. May be an image of body of water and nature.
Photo by Gary Sutton on July 14, 2021. May be an image of body of water and nature.

node.text:
On our way back from leg 1 of our field season on the north island with @oceanwiseresearch . We have had lots of success encountering the A23, A25, A50, A54, G20, I65 and I27 northern resident matrilines. Had some really great encounters with some Bigg’s killer whales too including the T049As, T137s, T036A2, T036A3 and the T060s who stole the show when they started hunting a pacific white sided dolphin! I snapped at his shot of T060F in hot pursuit of it.

We were able to conduct photogrammetry flights over both ecotypes and look forward to analyzing some of that data and assessing the animals health.

We will be back in a couple of weeks to start leg 2, which will be about a month long. Looking forward to that and to follow that and more of our work, you can follow us at @oceanwiseresearch where we will be providing field season updates throughout the summer. You can also follow #owresearchupdates to keep up to date.

📷Credit: Ocean Wise Research, DFO Marine Mammal Licence, MML18

⚠️ It is illegal to fly drones or approach killer whales closer than 200m if not under permit.

#killerwhale #orca #research #whale #biggsarethebalance #idigthebiggs

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Gary Sutton on July 09, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
It’s been a great start with my new job at @oceanwiseresearch and the killer whale photogrammetry team!

For those that don’t know, our team uses drones to capture aerial photos of killer whales (mainly northern residents) to determine their “fatness” and relative health.

We have started the first leg of our field season up on the north island and had a very successful week so far. We have spent time with the A23, A25, A54, A50 and G20 northern resident matrilines, the T049A and T137 Bigg’s killer whale matrilines and various humpback whales including BCXuk2011#10 “Cutter” who is in the second picture here accompanied by a steller sea lion.

One of the highlights definitely came yesterday when we were able to conduct 12 successful flights over the A54s, A25s and A23s. The flight over A69 “Midsummer” and her new calf was particularly interesting as they were accompanied by roughly 10 Dalls porpoises. Although mom seemed rather annoyed with the porpoises, the little calf seemed to be having a good time chasing the porpoises around as you can see in this first photo.

To follow more of our work, you can follow us at @oceanwiseresearch 
where we will be providing field season updates throughout the summer. You can also follow #owresearchupdates to keep up to date.

📷Credit: Ocean Wise Research, DFO Marine Mammal Licence, MML18

⚠️ It is illegal to fly drones or approach killer whales closer than 200m if not under permit.

#killerwhale #orca #research #whale

node.text:
T099C engaging in some homo sapien viewing a few years ago. A total infringement on the “Be human wise guidelines”.

Note: we were abiding by the be whale wise guidelines but this little guy along with a couple others got really curious about us and came over for a look 👀. Can you see his eye?
#killerwhale #orca #whale #nikon #beautifulbritishcolumbia #explorebc #biggsarethebalance #idigthebiggs #imsweatingmakinganigpost #itssohot

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Gary Sutton on June 24, 2021. May be an image of body of water.

node.text:
A question I got asked almost every day when guiding…. Why do they breach? The reality is there are different theories and reasons why but I want to hear what you think. Why do they breach!? Regardless, it’s awesome seeing scenes like this one with T046B2.
#killerwhale #orca #nikon #beautifulbritishcolumbia #explorebc #biggskillerwhales #biggsarethebalance #whale #idigthebiggs #pacificnorthwest #pnw

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Gary Sutton on June 21, 2021 tagging @taslishaw, @mattmjking, and @ocean_eco. May be an image of nature and body of water.

node.text:
A sunset breach from T099C tonight right in Cowichan Bay….can’t think of any better way to end the day.
#killerwhale #orca #whale #nikon #nikontop #beautifulbritishcolumbia #explorebc #cowichanbay #biggsarethebalance #biggskillerwhales #idigthebiggs

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Gary Sutton on June 13, 2021. May be an image of body of water.

node.text:
“Spyhop Sunday”. T046C2 “Sam” spyhopping beside T036B3 outside of Maple Bay.
#killerwhale #orca #whale #nikon #nikontop #pacificnorthwest #pnw #explorebc #beautifulbritishcolumbia #idigthebiggs #biggsarethebalance

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Gary Sutton on June 09, 2021. May be an image of body of water.

node.text:
Being an apex predator in the ocean comes with some consequences. One of them is the bioaccumulation of persistent organic pollutants like PCBs. These chemicals can pose serious threats to these animals and I’m looking forward to learning a lot more about it tomorrow when I’ll be hosting the season finale of Cetacean Sessions at 4 PM PST. If you’re interested in joining, it’s completely free and the link to register is posted in my bio under my linktree link. Hope to see you there!
#killerwhale #orca #whale #nikon #cetaceansessions #beautifbritishcolumbia #pnw #pacificnorthwest #biggsarethebalance #idigthebiggs
